info.headline: Winter Storm Watch issued January 01 at 3:50AM PST until January 04 at 12:00AM PST by NWS Medford
info.description: ...WINTER STORM WATCH IN EFFECT FROM LATE SUNDAY NIGHT THROUGH MONDAY EVENING... * WHAT...Heavy wet snow, with accumulations of 8 to 15 inches and locally higher amounts up to 20 inches possible. Winds could gust as high as 80 mph. * WHERE...South Central Siskiyou County including portions of highway 89 and Snowmans Summit, and in Eastern Siskiyou County between highway 89 and Tennant. * WHEN...From late Sunday night through Monday evening. * IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult to impossible. Patchy blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility. The hazardous conditions could impact the morning or evening commute. Very strong winds could cause extensive tree damage. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Monday morning, snowfall rates look reach 1"/hr at Snowmans Summit and could possibly do the same at Black Butte Summit (though for now forecast rates are closer 0.75"/hr at Black Butte). - The best forecast would suggest the snow level stays at or below the passes until Monday evening, but should the orographics of Mt. Shasta not be able to maintain the pool of colder air at the surface, the rate and amount of snowfall could come up short. - It seems likely that areas around the edge of the current watch area will meet winter weather advisory criteria. This would include portions of I-5 at Black Butte Summit and South of Dunsmuir, as well as the town of McCloud. * View the hazard area in detail at https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
info.instruction: * A Winter Storm Watch means there is potential for significant snow accumulations that may create dangerous travel. * Plan now to avoid traveling during the storm. * Have an emergency kit with tire chains, flashlight, batteries, blankets, food, water, and medications in your vehicle. * The safest place during a winter storm is indoors.
